;;大卫·卡梅伦在参加每周内阁会议后离开 10 号。
;

;大卫·卡梅伦面临电话通知在外交部拒绝透露他为了接任这一职务而放弃哪些工作和客户之后，他披露了他在被任命为外交大臣之前所工作的企业。

;

;这位前首相有过自 2016 年离开第 10 名以来，他从事过一系列工作，包括代表一家有争议、现已倒闭的金融公司 Greensill 游说政府，这导致了有关他影响力的丑闻。

;

;他还曾在一家基因测序公司 Illumina 在疫情期间赢得了 1.23 亿英镑的政府合同，还有一家人工智能公司 Afiniti，他于 2021 年从该公司辞职。

;

;一家名为 ChaChing 的电子商务公司最近出现在已将卡梅伦列为其顾问委员会成员，但相关页面已不再可用。该公司还聘请前财政大臣菲利普·哈蒙德作为顾问。

;

;卡梅伦似乎也一直在帮助;争取支持;斯里兰卡一个有争议的港口项目，该项目是旗舰;前总理向前同事发送了 62 条信息;，恳求他们帮助格林西尔，他曾在该公司工作，并拥有价值数千万美元的股票期权磅。调查发现;表现出;“严重缺乏判断力”。

;

;卡梅伦回避了有关他在;格林西尔;周一告诉记者：“所有这些事情都由财政部特别委员会和当时的其他调查处理了，就我而言，它们都已经解决了。”已处理过并已过去。”

;

;已联系卡梅伦和外交部征求意见。

;

; Wed, 15 Nov 2023 13:52:02 +0800 Manchester City post Premier League record revenue of £712.8mhttps://www.theguardian.com/football/2023/nov/15/manchester-city-post-premier-league-record-revenue
;;2023-11-15T05:00:09Z;
;
;;曼城对阵布莱顿的英超比赛前阿提哈德球场的全景。
;

;曼城宣布 2022-23 财年收入创纪录。俱乐部确认收入为 7.128 亿英镑，超过英超联赛纪录 6.484 亿英镑 ;混乱、偶尔精彩的切尔西表演，曼城很脆弱 |乔纳森·威尔逊;

; ;

;与上一年相比，俱乐部的转播收入增加了5040万英镑，并赢得了三冠王，此外净利润为121.7英镑截至 6 月 30 日的 12 个月内球员交易情况。大部分额外的电视收入可归因于曼城成功的欧冠联赛，最终以他们的成绩结束;6 月在伊斯坦布尔对阵国际米兰的比赛中赢得奖杯;。

;

;人数减少了 29 人俱乐部的工资在一个赛季中上涨了近 6000 万英镑，;埃尔林·哈兰德从多特蒙德队抵达;。工资支出增加的原因之一是向历史性三冠王球员支付的奖金。尽管员工工资支出大幅增加，但仍占收入的 59%，增长了一个百分点。

;

;上赛季阿提哈德球场进行了 31 场比赛，增加了 4 场，有助于每年的比赛日收入将增加 1740 万英镑，达到 7190 万英镑，这得益于平均出席人数的小幅增长。

; ;

;加布里埃尔·热苏斯和亚历山大·津琴科转会阿森纳以及拉希姆·斯特林转投切尔西带来了约 1.25 亿英镑的收入，帮助俱乐部在过去五个赛季的转会利润达到了 3.3 亿英镑。< /p>;

;“我们可以肯定地说，2022-23 赛季是曼城历史上最好的赛季，”首席执行官费兰·索里亚诺 (Ferran Soriano) 说道，他提到了三冠王、创纪录的收入和利润，被评为全球最佳赛季。曼城主席 Khaldoon al-Mubarak 表示：“我们的财务健康状况和球场上的成功意味着与曼城有联系的每个人都可以期待带着兴奋的心情展望未来。我们的集体成就给了我巨大的信心，相信我们可以在未来几年取得更大的成就。”

;

;城市面临的不仅仅是;100 项英超联赛指控; 涉嫌违反财务规则，俱乐部否定。这支七届英超冠军被指控未能“真实、公正地了解俱乐部的财务状况”，未能“包括球员和主教练薪酬的全部细节”，未能遵守有关财务公平竞争的规则以及未能配合四年多后结束的英超调查。这些指控列在账目中的“风险和不确定性”部分。

;

;曼城表示，有“全面且无可辩驳的证据”支持他们的立场。目前尚不清楚此案需要多长时间才能结案。

; Wed, 15 Nov 2023 13:22:02 +0800 India tunnel collapse: fears rise for trapped construction workers as some fall illhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/15/india-tunnel-collapse-trapped-construction-workers-ill

;
;;北阿坎德邦隧道塌陷导致 40 名工人被困，救援行动正在进行中
;

; 40 名建筑工人的恐惧与日俱增，他们;被困在倒塌的隧道中;超过 72 小时，救援工作受到新碎片的阻碍，里面的人开始报告生病。

;

;公路隧道这座位于北阿坎德邦山区的建筑在周日凌晨发生山体滑坡后倒塌。

;

;屋顶部分塌陷，数十名民工被困在 200 米深的地方。隧道入口被混凝土碎石、岩石和扭曲的金属堵塞。

;

;自周日以来，一场大规模的救援行动一直在进行，涉及重型机械、200 多名灾害管理和救援官员以及工程师，致力于清理隧道。碎片。超过20米的瓦砾已被清除，但还需要清除30米才能到达这些人的身边。

;

;当地县长阿布舍克·鲁赫拉(Abhishek Ruhela)告诉记者，“如果一切按计划进行，被困劳工将被周三之前撤离”。

; ;

;周二，3英尺宽的大型金属管被运至现场，希望在废墟中钻出竖井并插入管道，为工人创建逃生通道。然而，由于更多的瓦砾继续下落，而且钻井机械出现故障，救援工作受挫。

;

;“这些都是救援行动中的挑战，但我们会克服它们，”兰吉特·辛哈 (Ranjit Sinha) 说道。灾难管理官员说。

;

;氧气和装有干鹰嘴豆、干果、杏仁和爆米花的食品包已通过插入 40 米洞的小管道输送给 40 名工人。

;

;我们还通过对讲机保持持续联系，以保持工人的平静，并且一些家庭成员能够与被困人员进行简短的交谈。 “他说他们很安全。他让我们不要担心，”40 名被困工人之一的加巴尔·辛格·内吉 (Gabbar Singh Negi) 的儿子周二告诉记者。

;

;虽然官员们表示，隧道中有足够的氧气让这些人生存现场的一名医生表示，在五到六天的时间里，有几名男子开始抱怨出现令人担忧的症状，包括头晕、发烧和呕吐。

;

;与工人沟通的现场医生 BS Pokriyal 告诉记者。印度时报：“人们开始生病。我们提供了多种维生素，但我们无法发送 ORS [口服补水]袋，因为它可能会卡在用于沟通和输送食物和水的唯一管道内。”

;

;三英里 (作为 Char Dham 公路项目的一部分，Uttarkashi 地区正在修建 5 公里长的隧道，该项目旨在改善喜马拉雅山北阿坎德邦的连通性。

;

;然而，事实证明，这个雄心勃勃的项目颇具争议，环保人士声称，为修建和扩建道路而进行的大量钻探和施工正在造成脆弱的喜马拉雅地区的沉降、山体滑坡和严重的环境破坏。

;

;北阿坎德邦政府已成立一个专家委员会来调查问题的原因隧道灾难。

; Wed, 15 Nov 2023 13:22:02 +0800 Acting Spanish PM on verge of second term after controversial Catalan amnesty dealhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/15/acting-spanish-pm-pedro-sanchez-on-verge-of-second-term-after-controversial-catalan-amnesty-deal
;;2023-11-15T05:00:08Z;
;
;;西班牙代理总理佩德罗·桑切斯。
;

;佩德罗·桑切斯即将赢得国会支持在同意对数百名参与;六年前推动地区独立失败;。

;

;周三的授职辩论 - 这将是随后在周四举行的投票中，这位社会主义领导人已经掌握了获胜的人数——预计将结束;7月的临时大选没有结果;。

;

;尽管保守派人民党（PP）以微弱优势落败桑切斯领导的西班牙社会主义工人党 (PSOE)，;事实证明，即使得到极右翼 Vox 党和其他较小团体的支持，它也无法组建政府。

;

;西班牙社会工人党及其合作伙伴左翼苏马尔联盟通过争取加泰罗尼亚和巴斯克民族主义者以及其他地区政党的支持，成功地获得了必要的选票。

;

;然而，谈判并不便宜或容易。加泰罗尼亚的两个主要支持独立政党 - 务实的加泰罗尼亚左翼共和党 (ERC) 和更强硬的加泰罗尼亚联合党 (Junts per Catalunya) - ;只有在桑切斯接受了他们的特赦要求后才同意支持他们;。

; < p>;根据西班牙社会工人党周一提出的法律草案，特赦将适用于数百人，其中包括 Junts 的领导人 ;加泰罗尼亚前总统卡莱斯·普伊格德蒙特 (Carles Puigdemont);，他逃离西班牙，以避免因在策划失败的分裂国家企图中所扮演的角色而被捕2017 年 10 月。

;
;

;;相关：;;西班牙各地针对加泰罗尼亚分离主义者的特赦协议举行了新的抗议活动;

;
;

;桑切斯认为，特赦将有助于治愈过去和现在的创伤

;

;但大赦法激怒了人民党和 Vox，他们指责代理总理贬低民主，并利用大赦作为继续掌权的愤世嫉俗的策略。

; < p>;长期以来一直攻击这位社会党领导人对加泰罗尼亚和巴斯克民族主义者的依赖的两党也指出，桑切斯在大选前明确排除了大赦，理由是这与宪法不相容。< /p>;

;最近的一项民意调查显示;70 ％的西班牙选民;也反对大赦法，并且;上周日，西班牙各地举行了大规模的反对此举的示威活动;。

;

;最近几天，Vox 政界人士也参加了;西班牙社会工人党马德里总部外的抗议;最终导致警察和法西斯之间的小规模冲突，新法西斯团体。

;

;周二，人民党领导人阿尔贝托·努涅斯·费霍 (Alberto Núñez Feijóo) 表示，西班牙正面临“前所未有的局面”，;呼吁欧盟对特赦法进行权衡;。

; <另一位人民党高级人士将这次特赦比作佛朗哥独裁统治期间引入的立法，而马德里地区民粹主义人民党主席伊莎贝尔·迪亚斯·阿尤索则表示，桑切斯终于揭露了他的“极权主义”计划，并“迎来了独裁统治”。 ”。

;

;代理政府的消息人士将这些建议视为世界末日般的胡言乱语，并表示这些建议只是为了表明人民党与极右翼竞争对手有多么相似。

;

; Vox 领导人圣地亚哥·阿巴斯卡 (Santiago Abascal) 将桑切斯与加泰罗尼亚各方的协议描述为“一场大写字母的政变”，并表示这是“过去 40 年来西班牙政治中最微妙的时刻”。< /p>;

;他还呼吁进行“永久、和平的动员”，这远远超出了周日的一次性示威活动。

;

;桑切斯看守政府内部的消息人士称，大赦法完全符合社会党领导的政府努力平息紧张局势，并为所谓的加泰罗尼亚问题找到政治解决方案。

;

;虽然桑切斯一再排除就加泰罗尼亚自决举行公投的可能性，但他对该问题表现出了明显的和解态度两年前;赦免了九名加泰罗尼亚独立领导人的角色试图与西班牙分裂;。

;

;桑切斯本人已敦促人民党表现出“良好的理智”，并停止试图煽动事态。

;

;“我问他们尊重投票箱的结果以及我们即将组建的政府的合法性，”他周六表示。

;

;“我要求他们勇敢起来，对极右翼的熊抱说不，放弃他们目前走向深渊的反动道路。我们将为所有西班牙人执政——争取四年的社会进步和共存。”

; Wed, 15 Nov 2023 13:22:02 +0800 Crunch moment for Sunak as supreme court decides on legality of Rwanda policyhttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/nov/15/crunch-moment-for-sunak-as-supreme-court-decides-on-legality-of-rwanda-policy
;;2023-11-15T05:00:09Z;
;
;;Rishi Sunak
;

;Rishi Sunak 的旗舰移民政策在周三面临着关键时刻，当时最高法院将决定将寻求庇护者驱逐到卢旺达是否合法。

;

;最高法院的五名法官将就政府驱逐 10 名寻求庇护者的计划发布决定，这是保守党移民的核心内容鲍里斯·约翰逊、利兹·特拉斯和苏纳克政府的政策。

;

;有利于政府的决定可能会导致寻求庇护者被拖上飞机并送往 4,000 英里外的东非 — — 苏纳克认为这是一项政策将会受到该党核心选民的欢迎。

;

;这项裁决是在苏纳克面临危险的时刻作出的，他在;解雇苏埃拉·布雷弗曼(Suella Braverman)内政大臣。;

;

;如果政府输了，它将导致数十名保守党议员提出要求，政府将在下次大选中将欧洲人权公约作为该党宣言的核心。

;

;极右翼保守党议员的会议将在周三上午 10 点 30 分举行审议判决。如果它违背政府，预计会议将支持退出公约的呼吁。

;

;在周二的一封爆炸性信中，布雷弗曼指责首相违反了一项在英国法律中插入条款的协议，这些条款将利用公约和人权法“阻止”了对卢旺达计划的法律挑战。

;

;她说，他没有“可信的 B 计划”，并警告说：“如果我们在最高法院输了，我一直认为我们必须做好准备的结果，你会浪费一年的时间和一项议会法案，结果却回到原点。”

;

;她还说，如果政府获胜，判决仍将面临法律挑战。

;

;如果政府获胜，内政部消息人士称，二月份之前不会有任何航班起飞，内政部将其称为“软启动”。

;

; >;

;申请人预计将考虑该判决是否为将案件提交至斯特拉斯堡的欧洲人权法院 (ECHR) 留下余地，并可请求另一项临时禁令，停止飞往卢旺达的航班，直至案件得到充分审议。斯特拉斯堡。

;
;

;;相关：;;布雷弗曼在猛烈攻击总理后密谋保守党叛乱卢旺达计划;

;
;

;如果政府输了部长们预计将探索其他选择，包括与卢旺达达成新协议，解决最高法院的判决和卢旺达体系中的任何缺陷。

;

;他们可能会在议会批准的情况下将现有协议提升为条约地位，从而使其变得更加困难让法院介入。

;

;另一种选择是扩大《非法移民法》规定的国家名单，这些国家的国民的申诉将自动不予受理并可以迅速被遣返。

;

;Enver Solomon难民委员会首席执行官表示：“由于与我们合作的人员担心他们可能被送往卢旺达，我们已经看到痛苦、焦虑和更广泛的心理健康问题有所增加。

; < p>;“我们不应该将我们为逃亡者（包括来自阿富汗和苏丹的人们）提供安全避难所的国际承诺外包出去，而应该专注于运营一个有序、人道和公平的庇护系统。”

; Wed, 15 Nov 2023 13:22:02 +0800 Cop28 host UAE has world’s biggest climate-busting oil plans, data indicateshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/nov/15/cop28-host-uae-oil-plans-data
;;2023-11-15T05:00:06Z;
;
;;鲁韦斯炼油厂和石化联合体，由 Adnoc 在阿拉伯联合酋长国运营。
;

;最新数据显示，阿拉伯联合酋长国国家石油公司的首席执行官将主持即将举行的联合国气候谈判，该公司拥有世界上最大的净零破坏扩张计划。

;

;Sultan Al Jaber 是阿布扎比国家石油公司 (Adnoc) 的首席执行官，也是 11 月 30 日开幕的 Cop28 峰会的主席。新数据背后的研究人员表示，阿布扎比国家石油公司大规模计划的石油和天然气生产扩张存在明显的利益冲突，他们表示他的立场“荒谬”。

;

;At ;Cop28;，各国将尝试同意减少化石燃料的使用并将可再生能源的使用增加三倍。这次峰会在年底举行，;全球气温飙升;，极端天气的强烈影响毁掉了人们的生活，并且一再警告世界已经制定了利用;化石燃料储量;远远超过可以安全燃烧的数量。

; <图 data-media-id="895e5115e7360c15599e4a906f798b6c5abedc99">; ; ; ;

;数据来自;全球石油和天然气退出名单;（Gogel），这是一个公开的数据库详细介绍了 1,600 多家公司的活动，这些公司占全球产量的 95%。数据显示，几乎所有公司都无视气候科学家的警告，即如果要将全球气温上升控制在国际商定的1.5摄氏度限度内，就无法开发新的油气田。它还显示：

;

;联合国上周警告称，化石燃料生产商正在计划扩张，这将使地球的碳预算增加两倍。专家将这些计划称为; “疯狂”;并表示他们“让人类的未来受到质疑”。 ;一系列科学研究;得出的结论是，大多数现有石油、天然气和煤炭储量需要保留在地下，以应对气候紧急情况，但主要化石燃料公司和石油国家尚未停止勘探更多。

;

;

;“该行业扩张计划的规模确实令人恐惧，”石油和天然气研究主管尼尔斯·巴特奇(Nils Bartsch)表示在非政府组织 Urgewald 工作，该组织与合作伙伴一起制作 Gogel。 “为了保持 1.5 摄氏度的增长，石油和天然气产量快速、有控制地下降至关重要。相反，石油和天然气公司正在搭建一座通向气候混乱的桥梁。”

;

;Bartsch 批评了 Al Jaber 的双重角色。 “我认为这很荒谬。我不确定负责这种石油和天然气扩张的人如何适合领导气候谈判。这是最明显的利益冲突。”他说。

;

;Adnoc 发言人表示：“这份报告中有关 Adnoc 的数据和假设是不正确且具有误导性的。”该公司没有提供其计划的石油和天然气产量扩张的数据。

;

;发言人表示：“随着全球人口不断增长，寻求普遍获得能源，当前的所有能源转型方案，包括通过IEA [国际能源署] 承认需要石油和天然气来满足未来的能源需求。 Adnoc 生产一些世界上碳密集度最低的石油和天然气。”

;Gogel 数据库是使用行业标准数据提供商 Rystad 的信息构建的。 The researchers used the latest net zero scenario from the ;IEA; to calculate the overshoot in each company's oil and gas expansion plans.

;

;The IEA scenario sets out a feasible path to net zero emissions by 2050 that is consistent with keeping global heating to below 1.5C. No new oil and gas production can occur after 2023 in this scenario, so plans for production after this date overshoot the scenario. On this basis, Adnoc has the biggest expansion plans that are incompatible with the 1.5C limit.

; ;

;Previous analysis, revealed by the Guardian in April, showed Adnoc having the ;third biggest net-zero-busting plans;, after Saudi Aramco and QatarEnergy. That was based on an earlier IEA scenario.

;

;Adnoc has more planned expansion due to be approved after 2023 than other companies and is therefore top in the updated analysis.

;

;Politico revealed recently that Adnoc was ;delaying a competition; for drilling leases until after Cop28, according to a leaked internal document.

;

;The other companies in the top three for overshoots of 1.5C are the National Iranian Oil Company and ExxonMobil.

;

;The IEA's new 2023 scenario requires a sharper annual fall in oil and gas production than before and also includes future stranded assets for the first time, ie oil and gas facilities that have to be shut down before the end of their economic lifetime in order to meet climate goals.

;

;The companies that spent billions of dollars from 2021 to 2023 on exploration were led by China's CNPC and CNOOC, followed by Saudi Aramco and Pemex, Mexico's state-owned oil company.

;

;The Gogel database also shows companies are planning to increase global LNG export capacity by 162%, despite analysis suggesting the fuel may be ;more polluting than coal;. The expansion is led by the US, with 21 new LNG export facilities planned along the Gulf coast accounting for 41% of global LNG export expansion. Much of the gas will come from fracking in the Permian Basin.

; Wed, 15 Nov 2023 13:22:02 +0800 Chelsea FC face new questions over how Roman Abramovich funded successhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/15/chelsea-fc-face-new-questions-over-how-roman-abramovich-funded-success
;;2023-11-15T05:00:07Z;
;
;;chelsea
;

;Chelsea FC face fresh questions over how its former owner Roman Abramovich funded the club's success, after leaked files revealed a string of secret payments that may have breached strict football rules, including those on “financial fair play”.

;

;Experts said the transactions, uncovered through a joint investigation by the Guardian and international partners, could lead to the Premier League imposing punishments on Chelsea, such as a deduction of points.

;

;The files reveal a series of payments worth tens of millions of pounds over a decade, routed through offshore vehicles belonging to Abramovich. The transactions in question appear to have been for Chelsea's benefit, raising questions about whether they were declared in accounts submitted to football's governing bodies.

; ;

;Beneficiaries appear to include the agent of the star player Eden Hazard, an associate of the title-winning manager Antonio Conte and Chelsea FC officials. Other payments appear to have been connected to the purchase of the players Willian and Samuel Eto'o.

;

;The payments have come to light thanks to an international investigation known as Cyprus Confidential, a cache of 3.6m offshore records leaked to the ;International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ); and Germany's ;Paper Trail Media;, which shared access with the Guardian, the Bureau of Investigative Journalism (TBIJ) and other media.

; ;

;Chelsea's finances are already being examined by the Premier League in an investigation that runs from 2012 to 2019, after the west London club's new ownership regime ;voluntarily reported; that “incomplete financial information” had been submitted during Abramovich's tenure.

; ;

;The Football Association confirmed to the Guardian that it is also investigating Chelsea while Uefa, the governing body of European football, has already fined the club £8.6m over the admission, although its powers are limited because it can only look at evidence going back three years.

;

;Now documents, dated during and outside the period under scrutiny, raise fresh questions over whether Abramovich repeatedly flouted the rules of football to benefit Chelsea, as the club ascended to the pinnacle of the global game.

;

;Off-book payments

;

;Roman Abramovich bought Chelsea for £140m in 2003 and quickly ;flooded the club with cash; in a relentless push for success.

;

;The “Roman empire”, as some fans dubbed it, only fell when Russia's 2022 invasion of Ukraine led to Abramovich being placed under sanctions by the UK, ultimately forcing him to sell.

; ;

;Files analysed by the Guardian and TBIJ as part of the Cyprus Confidential investigation shed light on apparently hidden payments linked to pivotal moments in his trophy-laden tenure. The material, which comes from a Cypriot offshore services provider called MeritServus, was shared with the ICIJ by the nonprofit group Distributed Denial of Secrets.

;

;On 18 July 2017, the files show, an Abramovich-owned company called Conibair Holdings, based in the British Virgin Islands (BVIs), signed an agreement with Federico Pastorello, an Italian football agent.

;

;The Italian has been described in multiple reports as being close to Antonio Conte, the former Chelsea manager, and has spoken about the manager's contract negotiations in the media.

;

;Conibair agreed to pay Pastorello £10m for a 75% stake in Excellence Investment Fund (EIF), a business based in the US state of Delaware, documents suggest.

;

;That same day, Chelsea announced that Conte, who had just guided the club to the Premier League title, had ;signed a new £9.6ma-year contract;.

;

;Pastorello declined to comment on whether the two deals were linked but said: “Antonio Conte is not our client.”

; ;

;During Conte's title-winning season, Hazard scored 16 goals, a high point in a glittering seven-year spell that included him captaining the club and winning six domestic and European trophies.

;

;Hazard had ;joined Chelsea in 2012 for €35m;, in a marquee signing that followed fraught negotiations with the player's agent, John Bico-Penaque, who reportedly wanted a sizeable commission worth about £6m.

;

;On 29 March 2013, documents suggest, BVI-based Leiston Holdings, owned by Abramovich, agreed to pay €7m to a Dubai-based company called Gulf Value FZE for “advisory services […] related to […] sport research and consultancy”.

;

;The contract was signed on the company's behalf by Bico-Penaque. It is unclear whether the payment was declared to footballing authorities including the FA and Bico-Penaque did not return requests for comment.

;

;On another occasion, Leiston paid £1m to Association des Jeunes Espoirs de Bobo, the former club of Bertrand Traoré, via a contract signed by Traoré's brother, David. The contract is dated two months after the full-back signed for Chelsea.

; ;

;The files also reveal at least €7m in payments made between 2005 and 2017 to companies linked to Zoran and Vladica Lemić. The latter, a key adviser to Abramovich, was reportedly a pivotal figure in the arrival of stars such as Arjen Robben, Branislav Ivanović, Nemanja Matić and the double-winning coach Carlo Ancelotti.

;

;Separate documents show a £250,000 payment to the former Chelsea sporting director Frank Arnesen. Arnesen told the Guardian he would usually have expected the payment, a discretionary bonus, to have come from Chelsea rather than another company, but was unaware of any rule breaches and had declared it for tax purposes.

;

;Four leading sports lawyers told the Guardian that some of; ;the payments may have broken rules including Premier League and Uefa regulations on financial fair play (FFP).

;

;FFP was introduced by Uefa at the start of the 2011-12 season – with similar restrictions adopted two years later by the Premier League.

;

;The measures are partly aimed at preventing reckless spending that might put clubs' future at risk. But the rules have also been adapted in response to a trend of wealthy benefactors – including Abramovich and nation states such as Qatar and the United Arab Emirates – pouring their own cash into clubs to buy success, in a practice dubbed “financial doping” by the former Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger.

;

;Samuel Cuthbert, a sports barrister at Outer Temple Chamber, said: “If a club were to hide outgoings […] by paying those sums through other entities, it is conceivable that they could be in breach of the FFP rules.

;

;“You would effectively be circumventing your regulatory requirements, which limit your ability to spend, and spending instead through an offshore company.

;

;“Any opportunity to gain an unfair advantage skews the competition in favour of a particular club, and undermines the integrity of football, on a fundamental principled level.”

;

;Three other lawyers, who asked not to be named due to potential conflicts of interest, gave the same opinion.

;

;They also said some of the transactions may have broken Premier League rules that require the submission of accurate accounts, another provision demanding that clubs act in good faith, and the Football Association's rules requiring disclosure of payments to agents.

;

;The football finance expert Kieran Maguire, the author of The Price of Football, said Chelsea's huge spending meant the club had habitually flirted with hard limits on financial losses.

;

;“If there is proof that the club has used third party transactions to circumvent the profitability and sustainability rules then sanctions would be either financial or a points deduction,” he said.

;

;“The latter is more likely as any commission investigating a club's circumstances will want to put out a deterrent that dissuades others from repeating such behaviour.”

;

;Clive Betts MP, the chair of the all-party parliamentary group on football, said FFP should be “one of the key issues” for the new ;independent football regulator; being set up by the UK government.

;

;“It's no use having FFP rules if you don't enforce them, otherwise they're a smokescreen for clubs spending as much money as they want,” he said.

; ;

;The files also suggest that Abramovich secretly bankrolled efforts to overturn the FFP rules through the courts, ultimately unsuccessfully.

;

;In February 2014, Abramovich's Leiston Holdings agreed to pay £100,000 to a lawyer named Jean-Louis DuPont, who was challenging the legality and validity of FFP before the European Commission.

;

;Leiston, which is understood to have been acting on Chelsea's behalf, had a “business interest” in the outcome of the case, the contract shows.

;

;Eto'o and Willian

;

;A company owned by Abramovich also made payments that appear to have benefited the owner of a club that sold two players to Chelsea shortly afterwards.

;

;The fortunes of Anzhi Makhachkala, a now defunct outfit from Dagestan, were briefly transformed when the Russian billionaire Suleiman Kerimov bought the club in 2011 and bankrolled big-money transfers.

;

;But in 2013, Kerimov ;pulled the plug on his free-spending strategy; and slashed Anzhi's budget, plunging the club into financial turmoil and forcing a fire sale of players.

;

;That summer, Chelsea signed two stars from Anzhi in two days. The Cameroonian striker Samuel Eto'o was the first to arrive, followed – somewhat controversially – by the 25-year-old forward Willian.

; ;

;The Brazilian, who went on to win multiple trophies with Chelsea, had been on the verge of signing for its London rivals Tottenham Hotspur until Abramovich reportedly ;hijacked the deal;, via a personal phone call to Kerimov.

;

;Two months earlier, the Abramovich-owned Leiston Holdings agreed to pay two companies connected to Kerimov for “services in […] relating to football, including scouting and other football-related advice”.

;

;Tobeo Services Inc and Fernington Invest Corp, both based in the BVIs, were each to be paid €12m, documents dated 10 June 2013 suggest.

;

;A Chelsea FC spokesperson said: “These allegations pre-date the club's current ownership. They are based on documents which the club has not been shown and do not relate to any individual who is presently at the club.”

;

;The spokesperson said that during the purchase of the club – by a consortium led by the US investor Todd Boehly – the buyers became aware of “potentially incomplete financial reporting concerning historical transactions during the club's previous ownership.

;

;“Immediately following the completion of the purchase, the club proactively self-reported these matters to all applicable football regulators.

; ;

;“In accordance with the club's ownership group's core principles of full compliance and transparency the club has proactively assisted the applicable regulators with their investigations and will continue to do so.”

;

;The Premier League declined to comment while its investigation is ongoing. An FA spokesperson said: “We are investigating.”

;

;Representatives of Roman Abramovich did not return requests for comment. Lawyers for Suleiman Kerimov did not return requests for comment. A request for comment from Bertrand and David Traoré, sent via Aston Villa FC, went unanswered. A request for comment to Top Sports Consulting, whose director is Zoran Lemić, went unanswered.

;

;;Additional reporting: Timo Schober, Christoph Winterbach;

;

;The Ukrainian president's chief of staff has acknowledged for the first time that Ukraine's forces in the Kherson region have a foothold on the eastern bank of the Dnipro river, potentially opening a new line of attack towards Crimea.

;
;

;;Related: ;;'We save 98% of our patients': inside a frontline Ukrainian field hospital;

;
;

;Russian troops abandoned the western bank of the river a year ago and took up positions on the eastern side from which they have been regularly shelling towns and villages opposite.

;

;The acknowledgment by Andriy Yermak that Kyiv's forces were established on the Dnipro's eastern bank followed weeks of contradictory reports.

;

;“Against all odds, Ukraine's defence forces have gained a foothold on the left [east] bank of the Dnipro,” Yermak said in an address to the Hudson Institute thinktank in the United States. The remarks were posted on the website of Ukraine's president, Volodymyr Zelenskiy.

;

;“Step by step, they are demilitarising Crimea,” he added, referring to the peninsula Russia seized in 2014. “We have covered 70% of the distance. And our counteroffensive is developing.”

;

;Zelenskiy said on Tuesday the defence of the shattered eastern city of Avdiivka was key to Kyiv's war plans, with heavy Russian losses there likely to undermine Moscow's conduct of the broader conflict.

;

;Moscow's forces have focused on eastern Ukraine since failing to advance on Kyiv in the first days of the February 2022 invasion. They have taken aim at Avdiivka since mid-October and officials from the town, which had a prewar population of 32,000, say not a single building remains intact.

;

;Zelenskiy, in his nightly video address, said Russian assaults in the eastern Donetsk region including Avdiivka had been “very intense”.

;

;“Russia is already losing men and equipment near Avdiivka faster and on a larger scale than, for example, near Bakhmut,” he said, referring to months of heavy fighting that culminated in Russian forces capturing the eastern town of Bakhmut in May.

;

;“Withstanding their pressure is extremely difficult … The more Russian forces that are destroyed near Avdiivka, the worse the overall situation will be for the enemy and the overall course of this war.”

;

;Official Russian accounts of fighting in the east made no mention of Avdiivka, though prominent Russian war blogger Rybar said there had been “some headway” in positions around the town.

;

;Bakhmut lies about 50km (31 miles) north of Avdiivka, which is 20km west of the Russian-held regional capital of Donetsk.

;

;Ukrainian military spokesperson Oleksandr Shtupun said fighting was heaviest south of Avdiivka.

;

;“Over the last three days, the occupiers have actively used guided aviation bombs in Donetsk region, particularly around Avdiivka,” Shtupun told national television. Ukrainian forces, he said, had repelled 18 Russian attacks over the past 24 hours.

;

;As Ukraine's four-month-old counteroffensive secures incremental gains, Ukrainian officials have been cautious in describing the activities of their forces on the east bank.

;

;Russia's military said last week that its forces had thwarted a Ukrainian attempt to forge a bridgehead on the eastern bank and on nearby islands, killing about 500 Ukrainian soldiers.

;

;In a highly unusual incident on Monday, two Russian state news agencies published alerts saying Moscow was moving troops to “more favourable positions” east of the Dnipro river, only to withdraw the information minutes later. Russia has sometimes used similar phrasing about moving troops to more advantageous positions to describe retreats.

;Salman Rushdie made a rare public appearance since he was stabbed and attacked at a literary event last year when the author collected an award Wednesday night at the Vaclav Havel Center in New York.

;

;It's one of a handful of times that Rushdie has spoken in-person at an event since he was hospitalized, and his surprise attendance wasn't publicized until the evening over concerns for his security. The New York police department was dispatched outside the venue.

;

;;Related: ;;Salman Rushdie expected to testify at stabbing trial in January;

;
;

;“I apologize for being a mystery guest,” said Rushdie, appearing on stage at the annual “Living in Truth” ceremony while wearing a black button up shirt and matching black suit. “我一点也不觉得神秘。 It just made my life a little bit simpler.”

;

;He received a standing ovation from the crowd.

;

;Rushdie has written more than a dozen novels, including The Satanic Verses in 1988. That novel was banned in Iran as blasphemous, and a fatwa calling for his death was issued by the country's then supreme leader Ayatollah Khomeini, which forced the writer into hiding.

;Thirty three years after the fatwa was issued Rushdie, 75, was seriously injured as he prepared to give a lecture at the Chautauqua Institution in western New York in August 2022. ;

;Hadi Matar, the man accused of stabbing him, is set to stand trial 8 January.

;

;Rushdie attended the ceremony at the Bohemian National Hall on the Upper East Side to accept the event's first ever lifetime disturbing the peace award.他从《德黑兰洛丽塔教学》一书的作者阿扎尔·纳菲西那里接受了这本书。 A crowd of about 150 guests, consisting of journalists, diplomats, artists and more were in attendance.

;

;Speaking on stage about his personal relationship with Václav Havel, the former president of the Czech Republic, who the event was honoring, Rushdie said: “Havel was a remarkable figure because he was able to be an artist at the same time as being an activist, and those things are not always easy to reconcile with each other.”

;

;“When I met him in Prague, I said: 'Are you still able to write?' “不，”他说，“我只能写演讲稿。” And he regretted that, but on the whole I think it was a tradeoff he was willing to make.”

;

;The Vaclav Havel Center said in a press release beforehand that the author “exemplifies everything that the award stands for”.

;

;“His forthright defense of freedom of expression emerges not only through his fiction, but also in the principled stances he takes in his trenchant commentaries and memoirs.”

;

;Speaking earlier last month when he received the Peace Prize of the German book trade in Frankfurt, Rushdie said: “We are living in a time I did not think I would have to live in.”

;

;“It is a time when educational institutions and libraries face censorship and hostility.”

;

;Appearing on stage in New York, Rushdie referenced this past event.

;

;“Three weeks ago, I was awarded the peace prize and here I am receiving a disturbing peace prize.其中一件事绝对是真的。 I'm not sure which one.”

;The ceremony also honored the Egyptian political theorist and blogger Alaa Abd El-Fattah with the disturbing the peace award to a courageous writer at risk.该奖项由他的姨妈 Ahdaf Soueif 领取，她为此专程前往纽约。 Fattah remains imprisoned in Egypt under what the Vaclav Havel Center calls “inhumane conditions”.

;Soueif herself is an acclaimed author and was shortlisted for the Booker prize in 1999 for her novel The Map of Love.

;“We do visit Alaa, he is allowed family visits now once a month for twenty minutes,” she said on stage.

;CBS journalist Leslie Stahl was also honored for her foreign policy coverage on national television.

; Wed, 15 Nov 2023 10:22:02 +0800 US army overturns 1917 convictions of 110 Black soldiers charged with mutinyhttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/nov/14/us-army-buffalo-soldiers-mutiny-1917-overturned-jim-crow
;;2023-11-15T01:25:17Z;
;
;;George Ruth Jr, talks to Buffalo Soldiers before an event recognizing the legacy of the soldiers from the 3rd Battalion, 24th Infantry Regiment on Monday.
;

;The US army is overturning the convictions of 110 Black soldiers – 19 of whom were executed – for a mutiny at a Houston military camp a century ago, an effort to atone for imposing harsh punishments linked to Jim Crow-era racism.

;
;

;;Related: ;;US military identifies five troops killed in Mediterranean Sea helicopter crash;

;
;

;US army officials announced the historic reversal Monday during a ceremony posthumously honoring the regiment known as the Buffalo Soldiers, who had been sent to Houston in 1917, during the first world war, to guard a military training facility. Clashes arose between the regiment and white police officers and civilians and 19 people were killed.

;

;“We cannot change the past; however, this decision provides the Army and the American people an opportunity to learn from this difficult moment in our history,” Gabe Camarillo, the under secretary of the army, said in a statement.

;

;The South Texas College of Law first requested the army look into the cases in October 2020 and again in December 2021. The army then received clemency petitions from retired general officers on behalf of the 110 soldiers.

;

;At the secretary of the army's petition, the army board for correction of military records reviewed records of the cases and found that “significant deficiencies permeated the cases”.根据军方的声明，诉讼程序被认为“根本上不公平”。 The board members unanimously recommended all convictions be set aside and the military service of the soldiers' to be characterized as “honorable”.

;

;Christine Wormuth, the secretary of the army, said in the statement that the move marks the army's acknowledgement of past mistakes and sets the record straight.

;

;“After a thorough review, the board has found that these soldiers were wrongly treated because of their race and were not given fair trials,” Wormuth said.

;

;Military records will be corrected to the extent possible to recognize service as honorable and their families might be eligible for compensation, according to the army.

;

;In August 1917, four months after the US entered the first world war, soldiers of the all-Black Third Battalion of the US Army's 24th Infantry Regiment, also known as the Buffalo Soldiers, marched into Houston where clashes erupted following racial provocations.

;

;The regiment had been sent to Houston to guard Camp Logan, which was under construction for the training of white soldiers who would be sent to France during the first world war. The city was then governed by Jim Crow laws and tensions boiled over.

;

;Law enforcement at the time described the events as a deadly and premeditated assault by the soldiers on a white population. Historians and advocates say the soldiers responded to what was thought to be a white mob heading for them.

;

;Out of 118 soldiers, 110 were found guilty in the largest murder trial in US history. Nineteen of them were hanged.

;

;According to the army's statement, the first executions happened secretly a day after sentencing. It led to immediate regulatory changes prohibiting future executions without review by the war department and the president.

;

;Families of the soldiers may be entitled to benefits and can apply through a US army board for correction of military records.

;

;“Today is a day I believed would happen,” Jason Holt, a descendant in attendance at the ceremony, said, according to the Houston Chronicle. “I always did.”

; Wed, 15 Nov 2023 09:52:01 +0800 Xi Jinping in US for first time in six years to meet with Biden and attend summithttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/14/china-xi-jinping-us-visit-joe-biden-apec

;Blinken did not mention China in his remarks, but his language echoed US rhetoric in recent years in which Washington has accused China of bullying smaller countries in the Indo-Pacific and trying to undermine what the US and its allies call the existing “rules-based” order.

;

;US trade representative Katherine Tai, who with Blinken opened the Apec ministerial session, said the San Francisco meeting came at a time of “great uncertainty and challenges” for the region. She noted increasing geopolitical tensions, fragile supply chains and a worsening climate crisis.

;

;Earlier, Biden said his goal in his talks with Xi would be to improve the relationship with China after a period of strained ties. He said he would seek to resume normal communications between the two superpowers, including military-to-military contacts.

;

;White House national security spokesperson John Kirby told reporters Biden and Xi would also talk about the Israel-Hamas conflict in Gaza as well as US efforts to support Ukraine in its battle to repel Russian invaders.

;

;Democratic senator Ben Cardin wrote to Biden to push for immediate freedom for Mark Swidan, Kai Li and David Lin, whom the US government has classified as wrongfully detained in China. Republicans and other Democrats have also called for their release.

;

;“With the holiday season approaching, and the opportunity to start the New Year on a more positive note in bilateral US-China relationships, I implore you to secure commitments from president Xi to release these Americans immediately,” Cardin wrote.

;

;Cardin also asked for the release and safety of US-based journalists' family members whom he said are missing, jailed or detained in China due to their connection to the journalists.

;

;Economic issues will be high on the agenda.

;

;Biden said the US does not want to decouple from China but wants to change the economic relationship for the better.

;

;His administration has made a push to “de-risk” some critical US supply chains from China as the two countries' economic and military competition has grown.

;

;But it has been careful to assure countries in the region, including China, that the US does not seek complete economic separation, a notion that has fueled concerns among Washington's partners and allies of a superpower showdown that would upend the global economy.

;

;The Chinese severed military-to-military contacts with the US after then-House of Representative speaker Nancy Pelosi visited democratically governed but Chinese-claimed Taiwan in August 2022.

;

;Restoring the contacts is a top US goal to avoid miscalculations between the two militaries.

;

;Relations between the two countries grew particularly frosty after Biden ordered the shooting down in February of a suspected Chinese spy balloon that flew over the US

;

;Top Biden administration officials have since visited Beijing and met with their counterparts in an effort to rebuild communications and trust.

; ;

;Several hundred mostly pro-China demonstrators carrying Chinese flags gathered outside the Chinese delegation's hotel ahead of Xi's arrival in the US.

;

;Larger protests, including by rights groups critical of Xi's policies in Tibet, Hong Kong and toward Muslim Uyghurs, are expected to gather near the summit venue on Wednesday.

;

;As Biden arrived in San Francisco, shortly before Xi was due to land, dueling demonstrators greeted his motorcade from the airport.一些人挥舞着中国国旗，举着呼吁“友好”和“温暖”的中美关系的横幅。 Others held signs condemning the Chinese Communist party.

;

;Earlier on Tuesday, a small aircraft flew circles over the Apec summit venue in downtown San Francisco, trailing a banner that read: “END CCP FREE CHINA FREE HK FREE TIBET FREE UIGHUR”, referring to China's treatment of Uyghurs, which the Biden administration calls “genocide”.
